Message.Title: DRAM $0.65 has entered into a formal agreement with AMD (NYSE:AMD) for the development of an AMD-branded version of Dataram’s RAMDisk software. Dataram is to market the product beneath the name Radeon RAMDisk and will target gaming enthusiasts. AMD plans to offer special Radeon RAMDisk incentives for those purchasing AMD Value, Entertainment, Performance and Radeon Edition memory products.
Message.Msg: DRAM with only 5M share float and $6 million market cap is super-undervalued trading at a 0.15 X Sales. DRAM was almost break-even before this gigantic news for tiny DRAM. The company has a strong balance sheet and ZERO debt. The new Radeon products will increase processing speeds by over 500% vs. conventional products. These products are initially aimed at the growing gaming industry but could be extrapolated to complex engineering simulation programs and other applications requiring super fast processing speeks DRAM could be a multi-bagger from here and it currently has no downside at today's rock-bottom prices

Message.Title: AMZN downside risk is much bigger than up
Message.Msg: One simple question for those long AMZN, What is its upside, $300 ? or $280 ? Its upside is very limited because it is one of the most overvalued stock in almost all aspects, PE, PB and even PS compare to its peers. What's the downside risk ? Go take a look at the Cisco 10-15 year history. Cisco can make more money than AMZN when it was in growth time, and Cisco products are more stick than Amazon in terms of loyalty of the customers. Now the competition is coming everywhere, from Walmart, BestBuy and many other smaller online retailers, which still have sales tax advantage, to B&N, Google, Apple, Oracle, Microsoft and IBM in cloud computing and contents business. Its growth is very limited, will see its growth slow down. Then, its trading pattern will be like Cisco from year 2001. There are still a lot of more undervalued stocks on the market, many of them traded under book values and with PE less than 10, such as some banks, insurances, and even some oil and energy are traded in this kind scenario. Their downside risk is much lower and upside is much higher.

Message.Title: $13 ereader
Message.Msg: Thanks to the ongoing war between Amazon and Barnes & Noble, today's eBook readers are as cheap as they've ever been. Likewise, they now pack more features than ever: from built-in backlights to 3G connectivity, these readers continue to influence how people consume text. However, a new German company by the name of Txtr is hoping to rattle the industry with its ultra-cheap eBook reader: the Txtr Beagle. Priced at $13 — no, that's not a misprint — it has the potential to become the least-expensive eBook reader to date ... but it comes with some serious compromises. For starters, at 5" it features a much smaller eInk display than many of today's traditional readers. The Kindle Paperwhite by comparison packs a 6" screen. Furthermore, the Beagle isn't touch-sensitive, and it lacks: a backlit display, WiFi, 3G ... and just about every feature we've grown to love in our eBook readers. More importantly, the Beagle can only load eBooks sent from your smartphone via a Bluetooth connection. To transfer books users must launch the Beagle app on their Android smartphone (an iOS app is forthcoming) and zap eBooks via Bluetooth to their Beagle device. But with 4GB of memory, the Beagle can only hold up to five eBooks at a time. Did we mention it runs on two AAA batteries? The Beagle is set to launch in Europe before this holiday season, but Txtr also has plans for a U.S. debut in the works. Engadget reports Txtr is in talks with Sprint and AT&T hoping they'll each offer the device with a small subsidy. Assuming it debuts at $13 with a 2-year smartphone purchase or renewal, is the Txtr Beagle cheap enough to lure you away from your Kindle? Or is this one smartphone accessory you wouldn't mind skipping? Sound off in the comments below.

Message.Title: This quarter will blow you away.
Message.Msg: They made an absolute fortune. There is not a brand on earth that can afford not to be on AMZN. Even when I was shorting this stock, I still had to buy lots of stuff on AMZN. Guess what they did at the beginning of 2012? They told nearly every vendor they had that they were taking an extra 15% margin. These guys having nothing but upside. Why do you think Best Buy, Walmart, and Target are hunting AMZN so hard right NOW? Because they're getting killed by them. Why do you think AMZN scheduled a webcast of their earnings? Because they're huge. I would add to my position in a minute right now.

Topic.Title: This quarter will blow you away.

Message.Msg: Good luck:)

Message.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...
Message.Msg: CNBC's Amazon versus BBY versus WMT segment was inane... I wonder when an analyst is going to ask for a specific breakdown on Prime saturation? What I mean by that is I strongly suspect the marginal value of incremental Prime subscriptions is declining and rapidly. There are only so many high value Amazon shoppers (one needs to have enough wealth to buy enough high value density items to make the math work). I suspect most of those self selected into Prime before the free video and Kindle Bundle giveaways. Thus, as the average annual purchases of a Prime member declines over time, even as Amazon continues to pay for content and shipping on low value density items, the economics turn... There are so many areas I could go to town on this scam. To the jackasses on TV saying WalMart cannot match Amazon on price. Sure it can. It may hurt margins this year. But, see what Amazon's economics look like if its negative working capital model starts to see revenue growth go negative... Everyone will make less money in real terms, including and particularly Amazon. #$%$...

Topic.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...

Topic.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...

Message.Msg: The 300 multiple is by choice and long term vision, I certainly wouldn;t agrue that AMZN is a huge bargain, but to think the business model doesn't work is silly. They also do a great job or capturing investors imagination by entering fields with almost limitless growth--cloud etc...we'll all have to see on 10/25. Bezos isn't a dummy, he knows he's got to make some money this qtr. All I can say is this--you can get anything on AMZN, and most people do. They carry a weeks supply of everything in robotic staffed warehouse in cheap parts of town. If you feel somehow, this is an inferior business model to modern retail, that's just silly. This quarters numbers are VITAL to them. I agree whoeheartedly that a big miss would knock this stock to 150 instantly, but a big hit has a fair shot of hitting 300...we'll see. Thsi debate we're having has gone on for 15 years and longs have certainly has the best of it so far.

Topic.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...

Message.Msg: Amazon's competitive advantage has peaked. WalMart and Costco have superior cost structures for the forward looking environment and they, not mom and pop, are the competitive set now. Amazon has over invested in robotics, but that will be one clear in time. The announcement that is really going to shock people is when manufacturers decide to end the negative working capital environment. Certainly the brands with power can/should demand 30days or cutoff product. Then others would follow. A reversal in payment terms by all tablet/phone manufacturers (applied to all categories of products they sell including TV, video, stereo, PC, etc} would put Amazon in a WORLD of hurt heading into holiday 2012. Do the math. I hope Apple, Sony, Samsung, LG, HP, Google and other consumer electronics players do...

Topic.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...

Message.Msg: Wonder what the analysts models would get as a price target if the working capital model had to go from negative to positive due to "market conditions"? No cash left to invest in growth. Would need cash flow growth, not revenue growth, to finance any expansion. Too bad there will be so much cash tied up in Kindle Fire tablets which were completely unnecessary to execute the model. That and a $1B headquarters...

Topic.Title: CNBC is pathetic... Bring on people with intelligence...

Message.Msg: You don't even have to watch t.v., go on their website. Great piece today by Cramer! Top 10 momo's to buy for the last quarter of the year. Number one momo to buy!? AMZN!!! Cramer actually stated that AMZN is cheap! It only is trading at a PE of 35 if you take 2015 earnings.into account. It's cheap because your basing it on a growth rate of 36%. But he forgot that earnings are increasing so briskly because the company will eventually stop building distribution centers. What is the rev. growth rate??? Setting it up for one last pop. Come on Cramer pump! I need back in. - PJ
